content: all right let's see what I'm going to be building today well looks like I'm going
to the dollar store hey guys welcome back to black magic crafts I was not
sure what I was going to be doing for today's build so I decided to throw up a
quick community poll and let you guys decide would you rather see me combine
all the techniques that I've been using recently on my post-apocalyptic new
terrain stuff combine it into one big mega building thing or would you rather
see me attempt another dollar store challenge it's pretty clear you guys
wanted me to do another dollar store challenge I've decided I'm not gonna
place any arbitrary restrictions on myself in terms of what I can use it
just doesn't actually work in reality because every dollar store is very
different and they tend to vary a lot from country to country and even when I
try to do something that only uses really really cheap readily accessible
items there's always some ridiculous comments from people saying it doesn't
count and it's expensive because I own a desk or because I use scissors I didn't
account for the cost of scissors as if people don't own scissors come on people
that is no way to live just chill and try to enjoy things in life anyway my
idea this time around was to focus less on budget and focus entirely on
creativity I just wanted to go to the dollar store wander around and find
something interesting and inspiring to work with I went to Dollarama this
morning and yeah Dollarama isn't really like a true dollar store they tend to
sell items that are between one and five dollars so I guess it's more like a five
below or a bargain store but as a Canadian we call it a dollar store that
that's what we call it and if you don't like that you can fight us yeah game of
hockey I went to dollar hammer this morning I wandered around
my full intention was to find something to turn into a cool medieval fantasy
build so that I could not have three in a row that were futuristic that didn't
pan out however I came across these toy army tanks that completely grabbed my
attention this is the type of thing I would normally just walk right past but
now that I'm in the headspace of building futuristic or modern stuff all
the little details on these things really stood out to me so I bought
myself three of them I don't know what I'm going to make with them I hope it
turns into something good so wish me luck let's build
I really didn't have much of a plan
going into this one I knew there were lots of great details on these things
but I didn't know how useable they'd actually be or how hard this plastic
would be to work with I figured the best plan of action would be to disassemble
the tanks to better assess what I had to work with I then started breaking down
some of the pieces into smaller parts thankfully this was a very soft plastic
while soft flexible plastics aren't ideal for gluing or painting they are a
lot easier to cut with a simple utility knife I was expecting to have to use a
rotary tool to cut these up but luckily my trusty Olfa knife got the job done
just fine word of caution though you really need to use some care when
cutting up stuff like this it's not flat smooth plastic and it requires some
force so once I had some pieces cut up I spent a considerable amount of time just
playing around with them and seeing how the different pieces fit together and
how they looked I really can't give a step-by-step instruction of what I did
here and if you get the exact same tanks to work with I really suggest you don't
even try to replicate what I did there are a ton of possibilities and the best
thing to do is just play around and see what you come up with I knew I wanted to
end up with some sort of small structures that have a bit of elevation
and a lot of site blocking to use as scatter terrain somehow I landed on
making these triangular bases out of these sides of the tank body gluing this
type of plastic together can be quite challenging hot glue really doesn't hold
very well and super glue with accelerant is usually the best choice for some
spots where pieces didn't line up in a great way for super glue I used the old
baking soda and super glue method to make a stronger bond that would also
fill the gaps two-part epoxy resin is also a really good option in terms of
its strength but it takes a few minutes to dry and you gotta hold it while you
do that the piece I created had a large hole through the center so I used some
chipboard to fill it from beneath and this also added a bit
of extra-strength i selected some of the most interesting flat panels from the
toy and used them to create little sections of wall on the platform since I
was attaching pieces to surfaces that had a lot of variation I again had to
utilize the super glue and baking soda gap-filling method in this case I was
actually intentionally sloppy and a bit overzealous with this as it would create
a great texture that would look like a weld in the metal after painting the
tank gun barrels made a great smoke stack that also doubled as a piece to
strengthen what was the weakest corner of the bases at this point there was
still a lot of areas of this thing that didn't really look great the chipboard
in the middle and the back of a lot of the wall sections that were just flat
plastic as well as some of the ugly gaps in the joints I used this corrugated
paper that I ordered off Amazon to hide all of the things that I didn't like
once painted this will look like corrugated metal and it will add another
element to the aesthetic of the piece all the bits from the tank will look
like big solid industrial steel but the corrugated bits will look more like
parts that were added later to repair damage and it's those sort of little
details that I really love about terrain this corrugated paper is really perfect
for this you can of course do similar things using cardboard where you remove
one layer of the paper but you need to find the right type of cardboard and it
does require a bit more effort this paper is the perfect size and it's ready
to use it's also really cheap so I think it's totally worth it I don't have a
link up on my essential equipment page for it but I'll put a link in the video
description if you want to grab some I think it is a must-have
for post-apocalyptic or modern terrain building I ended up making two of these
that were mirrored this way they could be used together to create a variety of
layouts or orientations in my head I kind of pictured these being entrances
to massive underground bunkers the big front panels look like they could drop
down to reveal ramps leading underground the best part is that I still have this
huge bag of leftover parts to make what I made I only used two of the tanks so I
have a full one that I didn't even touch and I still have about half of the
usable bits from those tanks left over so lots of stuff for future projects if
I want it was a pretty good deal i prime these with flat black spray primer
before getting to work on the painting and gray primer would have been a better
choice but I realized that the last minute I was out and I didn't want to
waste time going to get more now for the painting I did use my airbrush if you
don't own one don't let that scare you away from a project like this you can
absolutely just paint something like this with a brush I simply wanted to
utilize the tool that I have and I want to get better at using it a project like
this is a great opportunity for me to play around test techniques and improve
my skills I started by spraying everything out in a gun metal metallic I
knew that I was gonna be doing a lot more of this type of stuff going forward
so I recently treated myself and bought a set of the Vallejo model air metallics
having metallics that easily work with the airbrush straight out of the bottle
was a really fantastic thing and the coverage was really amazing I did end up
thinning them a bit and the coverage was still really really good meaning I can
get more out of the bottles I didn't want these to look like that clean
sci-fi futuristic style I wanted them to look like they'd seen a hundred years of
wear and tear my future world is one that is dark dirty and full on heavy
metal so I set to work making these look rusted and nasty I used a few colors of
brown to create a splotchy pattern all over the metal but still leaving little
bits of the metallic showing through the mission model rust paint again was an
absolute all on this project and I could have left
these like this but I really wanted to use this as an excuse to experiment I've
always wanted to try the chipped paint technique but with my usual fantasy work
I've never had a project that would suit it this was the perfect project to do it
on so I gave it a go keep in mind I have never ever done this before not even a
test piece but hey there's no fun in being afraid to try things I sprayed the
pieces with a cheap hairspray that actually ran back to the dollar store to
buy after leaving the hairspray to dry to the touch I then painted out the
whole piece using a very muted kind of greyish green a color that I thought
would be appropriate for a military complex I tried to avoid hitting the
sheet metal bits as I imagined that those were added to the structures after
the original paint job but my airbrush skills are not good enough to avoid
overspray I'll get to fixing that in a minute after letting the paint dry for
about 20 minutes I used a wet brush to start removing some of the paint I was
amazed at how easy this was to do and how effective the technique was
considering this was my first try I was really blown away by how good it looked
I thought this would be an advanced technique and I'm sure that after a lot
of practice you can do it much better but still it's really forgiving and
something I don't think anybody should be afraid to try I really wasn't happy
with the bit of overspray I got on the corrugated pieces so I went back in with
a paint brush and painted them again with the same gunmetal gray after that I
went back and repeated the same rusting techniques I had done previously
these pieces already looked pretty gnarly but I thought they could look
even more extreme I wanted to add some textured rust to the parts that were
heavily corroded again I wanted to test out something new for this so I tried
out this thick mud weathering effect from Vallejo and it worked absolutely
brilliantly as old heavy rust now for the tricky part of this video I wanted
to add lights to these smokestacks and I've been playing around with wiring up
my own lights in the past but I've always had a lot of difficulty finding
and ordering the correct parts it can be a bit overwhelming and to be honest I'm
totally lost my idea was to do this in a way that was more approachable to
everybody watching and just use modified dollar store tea lights I had done one
off camera to test out the procedure using a light that I had on hand and it
went great that tea light when taken apart had a
solid switch and an LED that had soldered leaves to the housing meaning
all I had to do was snip the leaves and extend them unfortunately the tea lights
that I bought the next day to do it again on camera
we're totally different anyone that has worked with these knows that sometimes
when you take them apart they basically just fall apart
everything is just friction fit including the switch and the leads from
the LED to the battery these ones are far harder to work with
I continued anyway for the sake of the project essentially I removed the LEDs
and soldered on lengths of small gauge wire I used that UV resin to quickly
coat and seal the exposed soldered areas before feeding them through the piece to
get the wire through I had to drill and ream out a big hole in the bottom of
that gun barrel once I got it through I carved up the flame cover from the
candle and fit it back in over the LED inside the barrel i reassemble the tea
light housing in order to preserve the switch and I got to be honest this was
an absolute I really have to take the time to source
out some proper micro sized toggle switches so I can avoid trying to reuse
these crappy bulky friction fit housings in the future I glued that housing to
the underside of the piece which in the end did give me a secure switch and an
easily accessible battery holder to defuse the light and make it look a bit
more like smoke and flame I took a tiny bit of cotton from a q-tip and pulled it
apart and glued it around the light with a light dusting of black paint from the
airbrush I had perfectly serviceable smoke this project had some frustrating
moments but overall I had more fun doing it then I've had building something in a
really long time it was really great to just kind of go at it without any plans
or ideas just a toy tank and some creativity it was also really exciting
to try so many different new things here I gotta say I'm totally pumped about the
whole chipped paint technique and just how easy it was if you want to grab any
tools or supplies for your builds and you want to help out the channel in the
process check out my essential equipment page at Blackmagic Craft dot CA for
links to the things that I use and recommend there are a few items in this
build that are not listed there so again I will put those in the video
description below if you enjoy my videos and they've helped you out if you get a
lot of value from them a great way you can give back and help me keep making
them is by supporting black magic crafts on patreon a few bucks there a month
goes a really long way and it allows me to dedicate my time and effort to this
channel I really hope you guys enjoyed this video if you did hit the like
button and let me know in the comments below again this isn't a step-by-step
tutorial I really just hope your takeaway here is to get out and look at
some things from a different perspective in order to find inspiration for
something cool and of course I hope it inspires you to not be afraid of trying
new things and new techniques because you might be amazed with just how easy
some of them are that's it for this week guys have a good
weekend
